data.text: Are Carbon Handlebars Suitable for Bikepacking?

Question/thoughts: Carbon bars for bikepacking and ability to carry the load of a handlebar bag?? Even more specifically, carbon bars on a single speed with bikepacking? I ask, because my dream is to attempt the CT on my SS bike. I‚Äôm currently running Race Face turbine alloy bars on the bike. I have a pair of race face carbon bars on my full-suspension bike and do notice a difference in hand fatigue on long rides with the alloy bars on the SS bike. Obviously, it‚Äôs a bit different riding style on the SS to the FS bike(more standing, torquing, etc on the SS), so I‚Äôm sure that contributes to the fatigue, but I‚Äôm just curious/concerned about the strength/capabilities of carbon bars loaded up with a handle bar bag over the long haul. Appreciate thoughts.
Trying to save 3 oz? Seems bikepacking is enough of a test for bars, bag weight, strap placement and coat scratches?

data.text: Some of your fatigue may be coming from a weak bar location. A bit too low or a stem a bit too long or your saddle a bit too far back. These can all result in too much weight on your hands. Also riding with slightly bent arms can decrease weight on your bars and increase shock absorption which reduces strain and stress, if your back can handle it.

data.text: Will be fine, carbon mountain bike bars are designed to handle the stresses of hardcore trails and big drop offs etc with a large portion of your body weight on the bars. They won‚Äôt even flinch at a handlebar bag weighing say 5kg. Not only that but your body weight goes on to the bars right at the end where it has the most leverage. If it can cope with this it can easily cope with a bar bag weighing a fraction of the amount fitted much closer to the centre of the bar.
